⚡️ “Cluster approach for Irish NGOs”
https://t.co/Fj1ozEyRqg
More info on international clusters for humanitarian responses here https://t.co/c7DvwJmqal
And have similar structures for other areas of social services on a sector & geographic basis
It could also focus on strategic responses as well as contingency planning and be a focus for crisis response
It would bring in standard measure and reporting, share information and practices, eliminate duplication
So for example NGOs provided with funding to address homelessness would be part of cluster to ensure co-ordination and accountability
I think there would be a benefit to the government adopting the UN cluster model as a guide for grant making & state-NGO parternship
DPER are introducing more & more government wide rules about funding NGOs especially on pay, procurement and financial reporting
Each department, and each sector has a different approach to grant funding, commissioning, monitoring and partnering
This happens in the health sector, disabilities services, children's services, care for the elderly, addiction response, homelessness etc
Almost uniquely Ireland provides many social services by the state grant funding for NGOs
I haven't worked directly in clusters, I hear they have their challenges, but I believe they are better than the alternative
They are supposed to ensure acccountability, co-ordinate action, eliminate duplication and share information among other things
Clusters are used to co-ordinate actions by all parties involved in a response
One UN agency and one INGO are appointed to jointly lead each cluster, and other agencies are part of the cluster
Clusters are established for different sectors, e.g. shelter, nutrition, education, water & sanitation
It was piloted in response to the 2005 Pakistan earthquake
The cluster approach is used in humanitarian responses to co-ordinate action between International NGOS & UN agencies
Could Irish Government-NGO relations work more effectively if they adopted the UN cluster approach?

The parable of the Good Samaritan (Luke 10:29-37) is very relevant to refugees & migrants
In Matthew 25:31-46 Jesus tells us that when we welcome the stranger we welcome him
The Beatitudes speak of mercy and persecution in broad terms Matthew 5:10-12
The nativity story has two; Luke 2:2 has Joseph & Mary displaced due to a Roman census, Matthew 2:13-15 has the Holy Family fleeing Herod
It's Sunday morning, so I'm thinking of Gospel passages referencing migration and refugees...
